reviewText:
Product received for free

Having completed all the achievements and the game receiving a patch, I've updated the review.


A unique and very nice take on the Tower Defence genre.
In One Troll Army you control a giant troll to protect the goblins fort from invading waves of attacking creatures whilst you manage the goblins to collect resources and build up the fort.
As well as building up the fort you can also upgrade the troll, giving yourself more HP, strength and even learning new combat skills.

A rather fun and slightly comical game with a nice graphic style.

My biggest issue with the game is the amount of content and reply there is. It can be quite easily finished within a day or two and doesn't provide much game play after beating the three mission maps, you're left with just a survival (endless) mode which is the same but starting again and you lose the upgrades you had on the troll gained during the three levels.
More Maps and different modes would really help make the game last longer and give more reason to play through again.

The music, whilst it's okay, is a little too cheerful and needs more of a beat to match the goblin and troll theme of the game.

There was several bugs during my play though but I was still able to complete it, it did cause there to be a little extra difficulty to it but it was manageable. Since completing it a patch was released to address some problems although I've not tested it and won't be able to without starting a new game. It's nice to see they're fixing the problems though.

Multiplayer is only available via Twitch, which is a little disappointing, while it's a nice idea it's not going to be for everyone.

Overall it's a good game and a lot of effort has gone in.
It was nice that it was released for free and definitely worth a try if you like Tower Defence or even a bit of hack and slash. Given the lack of content it's probably not something I would have bought for much, I'd much like to have seen more verity of game play and possibly a more direct multiplayer method.

Very enjoyable for a short time but not something I'm planning on going back to unless more is added.
I have no complaints about any of the content that is available.

There's no micro-transactions or anything you'd expect to find in a free game, you can purchase cosmetic DLC to help support the developers if you liked the game, something I'd like to see being done a lot more with other games. :)

Bite Size Review - One Troll Army

The Good:
+Art Style is Charming

I'm really impressed by this little gem. Even setting aside the fact that it's FREE, there is a lot here to enjoy.

Basically, you're a big troll protecting a little goblin fort from waves of attackers. What makes this special is the control you have over the fort. You upgrade various components (towers, walls, buildings) with materials gathered from the map in the periods between monster waves. You have total control over the distribution of labor among the goblins as well.

It feels like a mashup of Lords of the Realm, the very first Warcraft (which the art is clearly inspired by) and an action RPG.

Downsides are the sort of unwieldy control of the troll (takes some getting used to) and the mediocre tutorial system.

reviewText:
So I'm adventuring around, killing zombies in KF and blowing up cowboys in fist full of frags, when suddenly an urge envelops me. I desire a game where I control miniature goblins guarded by a giant troll, that can get two shot by a minotaur leader.

In all seriousness, this is a really fun, really interesting game that reminds me a lot of the old black and white games. It's nowhere near as indepth or having the same mechanics, but the feeling of looking after your little goblins by controlling this big ♥♥♥ troll is just nostalgic as hell.

I do have a few gripes with the game; the control methods are a bit clunky, the UI could be better designed and the goblin management could be far better than slider bars. But all in all, it's still incredible.

If this was a paid for game, I'd give all my money. Please keep improving this, or at least make a sequel! :D Just don't fall into micro transaction hell and I'll love you forever.

reviewText:
Great game for a free to play game, quite generous if you ask me!!

The game in a nut-shell:
You start with a bare bones base that is guarded by a huge Shrek looking troll. It would seem that the enemies from various places (Ninja Turtles universe) have taken a day off and decided to trash your base. You basically combine tower defence elements with a troll smashing to form the basic gameplay.

How the game works:
The game structure is based on going from wave to wave of enemies when once defeated you get a set amount of time to manage your workers (smaller trolls) and upgrade your base. For the most part the constant switching between phases keeps it interesting and fun though it's not to say individually the combat/base management are perfect in themselves.

Combat:
During combat segments you take control of the troll and face ever increasing waves of bad dudes. The combat system is a very basic diablo-isk top down battle system, which is successful in some regards. It is fun but it feels like it could be smoother and better balanced. For one, your troll never feels impactful or strong. He is actually quite easily overwhelmed and as the waves increase there seems to be a huge disparity between what the game expects you to do and what your troll can actually do. There is a generous death mechanic where you retain your progress but have your wave number winded back to an early (and easier) wave, which allows you to farm enough resources to bring your base to a level that's more consistent with the difficulty of the wave that you lost to. Whilst this mechanic does balance the game it feels like it was implemented to hide a design flaw, which would not be there if the balancing had been fine-tuned better.

That's not to say that's there isn't good components to the combat system, take the whirlwind ability which feels very impactful. You basically do a spin around and anyone around you gets pounded. Though, a MOBA style key bind would be magical as it's only clicking enabled at this point, which takes away from the action, especially as you gain more skills and have numerous icons.

In terms of the abilities, it's very hit and miss. You tend to favour some abilities with others being useless. The whirlwind is great but the charge isn't. I avoid the charge because it's wildly inaccurate and sometimes you can run off screen and lose time coming back to where you are. The taunt is another example, not only is the animation too long but the troll isn't all that tanky, this talent is mainly used to kite at best and that detracts from the idea of being a huge troll that smashes things.

My last thoughts on the combat system is that the troll doesn't feel fluid enough. He can barge through enemies if he picks up enough speed, which is great but when he is attacking and not using an ability it lacks impact. Thematically, is this a large powerful troll or not? It would be awesome if there could be a Dynasty Warrior feel to his attacks (and some abilities give that) because he is a huge creature but instead you sit there hitting one little dude at a time that has more health then it probably should meanwhile range enemies are picking away at your health. I can understand that the developers put in the addition of upgradeable towers but it still feels like combat hasn't got the right balance at this point.

I do want to note that it's strange that the troll uses the same resource to upgrade as your buildings do. Not sure why they didn't implement an XP system. You can only obtain gold during combat but gold is required for upgrading your troll and base improvements. Whilst there isn't a resource issue it doesn't quite fit. The current system isn't perfect but seems little counter intuitive.

Camera: One of the things that really stopped the flow of the action was the poor camera. For the most part it's a fixed angle. However, I have two main issues with it:

1) There is a side of your base that you cannot see and you have to bring your mouse over the base in order for it to go transparent. This doesn't always work so sometimes you cannot see how many enemies are there and what the hell your troll is hitting. Particularly frustrating because the defeat trigger is your base dying.

2)  You can run off the screen when you use charge!! Really poor design flaw.

BASE MANAGEMENT:
The base management and resource management system is well thought out (albeit not perfectly thought out). You have an option of four buildings which give you access to different things (Tavern - mercs, Barracks - upgrades, Town Hall - worker efficiency & Trading Post - market place to trade resources for gold). In addition to that you can upgrade your walls and up to four towers, the towers have additional specialisation options (such as archers or catapults).  In terms of resources you have gold & loot" (which is stuff picked up from dead enemies) and gatherable resources such as wood
recommended: whilst it isn't perfect the timing mechanic adds an interesting element of gameplay. You have a certain amount of time to improve your base so you prioritise what you want to do and this gives it some depth. Early to mid-game the decisions feel weighty and require you to make decisions and prioritise. For example
hoursPlayed: choosing between upgrading civil buildings (which gives you access to more workers
voteText: which will allow you to more but no defensive value) vs upgrading a tower/wall (which is your bases survivability). The idea is sound and interesting but a few things emerge as you go. Granted somethings are required (need the store house early or you get resource capped) other buildings you can go without for a long time (like Barracks

One troll army is about a group of goblins that pray to their gods for a beast that can help them defend their fortress so they can make it able to stand off attacks from the enemys that consist of animal people, not like half people half animals but more like animals that walk like humans, but still look more like the animals.
You controll a troll and a group of goblins. Your goal is to defend vs the enemys, get enough resources to upgrade your goblin fortress and the troll.
The troll can learn new attacks, become faster, have more health, hit harder and get more awesomeness.
The goblin fortress can get better trained workers, better trained tower guards, hired orcs, upgraded your 4 side's towers, the wall, new resources places, tavren, barracks, store and town hall.
There are 3 story missions. Strawburg, Timberpost and Stonehold, after the toturial/story missions you can go into surviver that is an everlasting one.
This game looks good and plays ok, the troll is alittle cluncky, but it has fair enough skills that is intressting to use. The enemys will become better as soon as the fortress becomes better, the store has a trading mechanics that allows you to chess the game out by harvesting the most expensive thing, make it into gold and then make it into what you need. This game NEEDS a hardcord setting cause you can not lose. I had it on hard and it was too easy anyways. The rts element is just to use money on the things you wanna upgrade, releasing the hired orcs and using the trolls skills. If this sounds like a good deal then give this free game with steam achievments a go. It looks really good for a free to play game and its kinda fun. Have fun and enjoy smashing pigmen. ;)
